results.title: Adult development
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Rachel Rosenthal and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
For all of us, adult life is full of transitions and turning points. How do adults develop psychologically? Do their changes follow some set course, or is their growth varied and unpredictable? This program examines the major transitions in adult life - leaving home, parenting, mid-life crisis and retirement, by interviewing both psychologists and adults going through each of these stages.

results.title: Intelligence
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Linda Jassim and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
How do you quantify differences in intelligence? How is intelligence determined? How can it be measured? Is it related to the brain? Can it ever be defined? Does heredity or experience define the upper limit of intelligence and what is the relationship between intelligence and motivation? These questions and the usefulness of intelligence tests are considered by a variety of psychologists.

results.title: The biology of behavior
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Steven Talley, David Stone and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Humans are quick thinking, quick acting animals. This ability to react is controlled by the nervous system, which in turn is controlled by a complex system of neurotransmitters in the brain. This program examines the operation of these neurotransmitters, their effect on individual personality and what happens when these networks break down due to neurotransmitter diseases, in particular, Parkinson’s Disease.

results.title: Issues in psychology
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, David Stone and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Psychology is a dynamic, diverse discipline concerned with the study of the human condition. What are the major issues in, and impact of, psychology today? To examine this question, a panel of US psychologists are assembled including psychobiologist, James McGaugh, social psychologist, Lee Ross, cognitive/social psychologist, Elizabeth Loftus, and Professor Joseph White, a developmental psychologist.

results.title: Conformity, obedience and dissent
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Leslie Hill and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Scientific experiments have consistently revealed how difficult it is for the individual to dissent or disobey within Western society. This video examines the psychological and social phenomena of conformity, obedience and dissent, using interviews with prominent US psychologists and referring to landmark experiments on obedience such as that conducted by Stanley Milgram. In this experiment, two-thirds of subjects applied increasingly powerful electric shocks as punishment simply because an authority figure told them to do so.

results.title: Discovering psychology
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: A challenging series of programs on human psychology hosted by veteran psychology professor, Philip Zimbardo of Stanford University. New developments are measured against historical breakthroughs and theories are tested by the recent findings of leading researchers.

results.title: New directions
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
Philip Zimbardo surveys a range of leading American psychologists to discover where they see psychology heading. Psychologists consulted include cognitive psychologist, Howard Gardiner and pioneer behaviourist, B. F. Skinner, both of Harvard University; psycholinguist, Jean Berko-Gleason; social behaviourist, Steven Suonin; neuroscientist, Richard Thompson of UCLA; and F.W. Putnam-Niha, specialist in multiple personality disorders.
results.description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Discovering psychology”.

Putnam-Niha, specialist in multiple personality disorders.

Episode number 26 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
Philip Zimbardo surveys a range of leading American psychologists to discover where they see psychology heading. Psychologists consulted include cognitive psychologist, Howard Gardiner and pioneer behaviourist, B. F. Skinner, both of Harvard University; psycholinguist, Jean Berko-Gleason; social behaviourist, Steven Suonin; neuroscientist, Richard Thompson of UCLA; and F.W. Putnam-Niha, specialist in multiple personality disorders.

results.title: A Union of opposites
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 25 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
In this penultimate episode in the series, Philip Zimbardo looks at the discipline of psychology in terms of reconciling opposites, in the same way as the yin and yang of Eastern philosophy. These include nature and nurture, brain and mind, conditioned responses and behavioural freedom, life span development from infancy to old age, the power and the fallibility of the mind and our role as individuals and as group members. Yet in spite of all the advances in psychological knowledge this century, we can still only suggest the complexity of human nature.

results.title: In space, toward peace
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
How can psychology aid astronauts in space? How can psychology end conflict that leads to war? In this program, Philip Zimbardo shows how psychologists can help astronauts battle physical stress, mental stress, anxiety, boredom and depression. He also examines the psychology of peace - the study of the process of dehumanisation in the nuclear arms race and the art of conciliation in negotiating for peace.
results.description:

results.title: Health, mind and behavior
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
In this program, Philip Zimbardo investigates the power the mind has on the functioning of our bodies, in particular, the effect of stress on our health. Increasingly, scientists have had to acknowledge this connection in treating human illness. Zimbardo reveals how a holistic approach to healing, which aims to keep mind and body in harmony, can reduce the impact of stress- related illness such as hypertension and improve the functioning of the human immune system.
